docs.title: Choosing Your MBASIC User Interface
docs.text: This guide helps you select the best MBASIC UI for your specific needs and use cases.

docs.title: Quick Decision Tree
docs.text:
Start Here
    ↓
Do you need a graphical interface?
    ├─ No → Do you have terminal access only?
    │        ├─ Yes → Use CURSES (full terminal IDE)
    │        └─ No → Use CLI (command line)
    │
    └─ Yes → Do you need to install software?
             ├─ No → Use WEB (browser-based)
             └─ Yes → Use TK (desktop GUI)

docs.title: UI Comparison at a Glance
docs.text: UI Best For Avoid If CLI Automation, testing, purists You want visual editing Curses SSH/remote, terminal fans You need mouse support Tk Full IDE experience You can't install Tkinter Web Sharing, teaching, quick access You need local files

docs.title: 🖥️ CLI (Command Line Interface)
docs.text:
Choose CLI when you: - Want the authentic MBASIC-80 experience - Need to automate with scripts - Run automated tests - Process batch files - Work with pipes and redirection - Debug with command-line tools - Have minimal resources

CLI is perfect for: 

# Automation
echo "10 PRINT \"Hello\"
20 END
RUN" | python3 mbasic

# Testing
python3 mbasic test.bas > output.txt

# Debugging
python3 mbasic --debug program.bas

Real-world use cases: - CI/CD pipelines - Automated testing - Batch processing - System administration - Learning classic BASIC - Minimal environments

Unique advantages: - Fastest startup time - Lowest memory usage - Best for scripting - Command-line debugging (BREAK, STEP, STACK commands) - True to original MBASIC

Limitations: - Line-by-line editing only - No visual debugging (text commands only) - No mouse support - No Save without filename

Note: CLI has full debugging capabilities through commands (BREAK, STEP, STACK), but lacks the visual debugging interface (Variables Window, clickable breakpoints, etc.) found in Curses, Tk, and Web UIs.

docs.title: 📟 Curses (Terminal UI)
docs.text:
Choose Curses when you: - Work over SSH/remote terminal - Prefer keyboard-only navigation - Like terminal applications - Need a TUI without X11 - Want split-screen editing - Use tmux/screen

Curses is perfect for: 

# SSH sessions
ssh server
python3 mbasic --ui curses

# Terminal multiplexers
tmux new
python3 mbasic --ui curses

# Console-only systems
# (no GUI installed)

Real-world use cases: - Remote development - Server administration - Embedded systems - Low-bandwidth connections - Terminal enthusiasts - Retro computing feel

Unique advantages: - Full IDE in terminal - Works over SSH - Keyboard shortcuts - Split-screen layout - Low bandwidth needs - No GUI dependencies

Limitations: - Limited mouse support - Partial variable editing - No clipboard integration - Terminal color limits - No Find/Replace

docs.title: 🪟 Tk (Desktop GUI)
docs.text:
Choose Tk when you: - Want a full-featured IDE - Need Find/Replace - Prefer mouse interaction - Want visual debugging - Edit multiple files - Need all features

Tk is perfect for: 

# Desktop development
python3 mbasic --ui tk

# Teaching/presentations
# (full visual interface)

# Complex debugging
# (visual breakpoints)

Real-world use cases: - Desktop development - Educational settings - Complex programs - Professional development - Documentation writing - Code demonstrations

Unique advantages: - Most complete feature set - Find/Replace dialogs - Smart Insert mode - Native file dialogs - Full debugging UI - Recent files list - Mouse support - Web browser help

Limitations: - Requires Tkinter - Desktop only - Larger resource usage - Not for remote access

docs.title: 🌐 Web (Browser-based)
docs.text:
Choose Web when you: - Can't install software - Need to share programs - Teach/learn BASIC - Want modern UI - Use multiple devices - Need zero setup

Web is perfect for: 

# Start server
python3 mbasic --ui web

# Open browser
http://localhost:8080

# Share with others
# (network accessible)

Real-world use cases: - Online tutorials - Classroom teaching - Quick demonstrations - Cross-platform access - Chromebook users - Tablet/mobile access

Unique advantages: - No installation - Modern interface - Auto-save - Browser-based - Touch support - Theme options - Share via URL - Conditional breakpoints

Limitations: - Needs web server - Browser storage only - No local file access - Session-based - Network dependency

docs.title: Scenario 1: Teaching a Class
docs.text:
Best choice: Web UI

Why: - Students need no installation - Share code via URL - Works on any device - Modern, familiar interface

Setup: 

# Teacher's machine
python3 mbasic --ui web --host 0.0.0.0

# Students browse to teacher's IP
http://teacher-ip:8080

docs.title: Scenario 2: Remote Server Development
docs.text:
Best choice: Curses UI

Why: - Works over SSH - Full IDE features - No X11 forwarding needed - Low bandwidth

Setup: 

ssh myserver
cd mbasic
python3 mbasic --ui curses

docs.title: Scenario 3: Automated Testing
docs.text:
Best choice: CLI

Why: - Scriptable - Fast execution - CI/CD friendly - Output capture

Setup: 

#!/bin/bash
for test in tests/*.bas; do
    python3 mbasic "$test" > "${test}.out"
    diff "${test}.out" "${test}.expected"
done

docs.title: Scenario 4: Professional Development
docs.text:
Best choice: Tk UI

Why: - Full IDE features - Find/Replace - Visual debugging - Best productivity

Setup: 

python3 mbasic --ui tk
# Or create desktop shortcut

docs.title: Scenario 5: Quick Program Testing
docs.text:
Best choice: CLI or Web

CLI for speed: 

python3 mbasic test.bas

Web for convenience: 

python3 mbasic --ui web --open

docs.title: Startup Time
docs.text:
1. CLI: ~0.1s (fastest)
  2. Curses: ~0.3s
  3. Tk: ~0.8s
  4. Web: ~2s (browser launch)

docs.title: Memory Usage (approximate)
docs.text:
1. CLI: 20MB (lowest)
  2. Curses: 25MB
  3. Tk: 40MB
  4. Web: 50MB+ (plus browser)

docs.title: Large File Handling
docs.text:
1. CLI: Best (streaming)
  2. Curses: Good
  3. Tk: Good
  4. Web: Limited (browser constraints)

docs.title: Execution Speed
docs.text: All UIs use the same interpreter core, so execution speed is identical. Differences appear in: - UI responsiveness - Display updates - Input handling

docs.title: CLI
docs.text:
# Just Python 3.8+
python3 mbasic

docs.title: Curses
docs.text:
# Requires urwid
pip install urwid
python3 mbasic --ui curses

docs.title: Tk
docs.text:
# Requires tkinter (usually pre-installed)
# Ubuntu/Debian:
sudo apt-get install python3-tk
python3 mbasic --ui tk

docs.title: Web
docs.text:
# Requires nicegui
pip install nicegui
python3 mbasic --ui web

docs.title: Moving from CLI to GUI
docs.text:
If you're comfortable with CLI but want GUI features:

  1. Start with Curses: Familiar commands, visual enhancement
  2. Try Tk next: Full GUI with familiar concepts
  3. Explore Web: Modern features, different paradigm

docs.title: Moving from GUI to CLI
docs.text:
If you know Tk/Web but need CLI:

  1. Learn commands: LOAD, SAVE, RUN, LIST
  2. Master line editing: Edit by number
  3. Use HELP often: Built-in documentation
  4. Practice debugging: BREAK, STEP, STACK

docs.title: Your Programs Work Everywhere
docs.text: Important: All UIs run the same MBASIC 5.21 interpreter. Your .bas files work identically in any UI.

docs.title: Multi-UI Workflow
docs.text: Many users combine UIs:

docs.title: Development Workflow
docs.text:
1. Write in Tk (best editor)
  2. Debug in Tk or Web (visual)
  3. Test in CLI (automation)
  4. Deploy in CLI (production)

docs.title: Teaching Workflow
docs.text:
1. Prepare in Tk (full features)
  2. Present in Web (students access)
  3. Test in CLI (quick checks)

docs.title: Remote Workflow
docs.text:
1. Develop locally in Tk
  2. Deploy remotely in CLI
  3. Debug remotely in Curses

docs.title: Can I use multiple UIs simultaneously?
docs.text:
Yes! Run different UIs in separate terminals: 

# Terminal 1
python3 mbasic --ui tk

# Terminal 2
python3 mbasic --ui curses

# Terminal 3
python3 mbasic --ui web

docs.title: Which UI is most compatible with original MBASIC?
docs.text: CLI is closest to original MBASIC-80. It maintains command compatibility and behavior.

docs.title: Which UI is best for beginners?
docs.text: Web for absolute beginners (familiar interface) Tk for those comfortable installing software CLI for those learning classic BASIC

docs.title: Can I switch UIs mid-project?
docs.text:
Yes! Save your program and open in another UI: 

# In CLI
SAVE "myprogram.bas"
SYSTEM

# Switch to Tk
python3 mbasic --ui tk
# Then: File → Open → myprogram.bas

docs.title: Which UI gets new features first?
docs.text: Features are typically added to: 1. Tk (most complete) 2. Web (modern features) 3. Curses (terminal features) 4. CLI (compatibility focused)

docs.title: Decision Matrix
docs.text: Factor CLI Curses Tk Web No dependencies ✅ ❌ ❌ ❌ Remote access ✅ ✅ ❌ ✅ Visual editing ❌ ✅ ✅ ✅ Mouse support ❌ ⚠️ Limited ✅ ✅ Find/Replace ❌ ❌ ✅ ❌ Debugging ✅ ✅ ✅ ✅ Automation ✅ ❌ ❌ ❌ Resource usage Low Low Med High Learning curve Med Low Low Low

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
There's no "best" UI—only the best UI for your current task:

  • CLI: When you need speed, scripting, or authenticity
  • Curses: When you're in a terminal and want an IDE
  • Tk: When you want all features on desktop
  • Web: When you need accessibility and sharing

Try them all and see what fits your workflow!

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
# Try each UI for 5 minutes:
python3 mbasic --ui cli
python3 mbasic --ui curses
python3 mbasic --ui tk
python3 mbasic --ui web

# Your favorite will become clear quickly!

docs.title: Line Endings (Newlines)
docs.text: MBASIC saves all program files using Unix-style line endings (\n, also called LF).

docs.title: What This Means
docs.text:
• Loading files: MBASIC automatically handles files with any line ending style:
  • Unix ( / LF)
  • Windows ( / CRLF)

  • Classic Mac ( / CR)

  • Saving files: MBASIC always saves with Unix line endings ( )

docs.title: Why Unix Line Endings?
docs.text:
• Cross-platform compatibility: Modern text editors on all platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux) handle LF correctly
  • Modern Windows support: Windows Notepad (since Windows 10 1809), VS Code, Notepad++, and other editors all support LF
  • Web UI consistency: Browser-based editing works the same on all operating systems
  • Git-friendly: Standard for version control systems

docs.title: Using Files with CP/M Emulators
docs.text: If you want to transfer saved BASIC files to a CP/M emulator (such as tnylpo), you may need to convert the line endings from LF (\n) to CRLF (\r\n), as CP/M systems expect CRLF line endings.

docs.title: Converting to CP/M Format
docs.text:
On Linux/Mac: 

# Convert LF to CRLF
unix2dos yourfile.bas

# Or using sed
sed -i 's/$/\r/' yourfile.bas

# Or using Python
python3 -c "import sys; data=open('yourfile.bas','rb').read(); open('yourfile.bas','wb').write(data.replace(b'\n',b'\r\n'))"

On Windows (PowerShell): 

# Using PowerShell to convert
(Get-Content yourfile.bas) | Set-Content yourfile.bas

Using a utility script:

MBASIC includes a utility script for CP/M conversion: 

# Convert a file to CP/M format (CRLF line endings)
python3 utils/convert_to_cpm.py yourfile.bas

docs.title: Assembly Source Files (.mac)
docs.text: Note: Assembly source files (.mac) in the docs/history/original_mbasic_src/ directory retain their original CRLF line endings because they are intended for use with the CP/M M80 assembler, which requires CRLF format.

docs.title: Character Encoding
docs.text:
MBASIC uses UTF-8 encoding for all files. However, when loading files:

  • Parity bits are cleared: High bit (bit 7) is stripped from characters
  • Control characters are filtered: Most control characters are removed (except CR, LF, TAB)
  • CP/M EOF markers removed: Ctrl+Z (\x1a) end-of-file markers are stripped

This ensures compatibility with files created on vintage systems that may have used 7-bit ASCII with parity or included CP/M-specific markers.

docs.title: File Extensions
docs.text:
MBASIC recognizes these file extensions:

  • .bas - Standard BASIC program files (recommended)
  • .BAS - Uppercase variant (also supported)
  • .txt - Plain text files containing BASIC code

All are treated identically when loading.

docs.title: Line Number Format
docs.text:
BASIC program lines must start with a line number (1-65535) followed by at least one space:

10 PRINT "HELLO"
20 FOR I=1 TO 10
30 PRINT I
40 NEXT I

Lines without line numbers are ignored when loading files.

docs.title: From Real MBASIC 5.21
docs.text: Files created with the original Microsoft MBASIC 5.21 (from CP/M systems) can be loaded directly. MBASIC will: - Convert CRLF line endings to LF automatically - Strip any CP/M EOF markers (^Z) - Clear parity bits if present

docs.title: To Real MBASIC 5.21
docs.text: To transfer files TO a real MBASIC 5.21 system or CP/M emulator: 1. Save the file in MBASIC 2. Convert line endings to CRLF (see "Converting to CP/M Format" above) 3. Optionally add CP/M EOF marker: echo -e '\x1a' >> yourfile.bas

docs.title: Other BASIC Dialects
docs.text: MBASIC implements the Microsoft MBASIC 5.21 dialect. Files from other BASIC interpreters (GW-BASIC, QBASIC, etc.) may load but could have syntax differences. See the language documentation for specifics.

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: This guide will help you install and run the MBASIC 5.21 Interpreter on your computer.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: You need Python 3.8 or later installed on your system.

docs.title: Check if Python is installed
docs.text:
Open a terminal (Command Prompt on Windows, Terminal on Mac/Linux) and run:

python3 --version

If you see a version number like Python 3.9.x or higher, you're good to go! If not, download Python from python.org.

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
MBASIC's dependencies depend on which UI mode you plan to use:

UI Mode External Dependencies CLI None (Python standard library only) Curses urwid (install via pip) Tk tkinter (usually pre-installed with Python) Web nicegui (install via pip)

If you only want CLI mode, you can skip all dependency installation steps. Just run python3 mbasic and you're ready to go!

For other UIs, use pip install -r requirements.txt to install the necessary dependencies.

docs.title: Method 1: Using Virtual Environment (Recommended)
docs.text: A virtual environment keeps this project's dependencies separate from your system Python. This is the recommended approach for Python projects.

docs.title: Step 1: Download the project
docs.text:
# Clone the repository (if using git)
git clone https://github.com/avwohl/mbasic.git
cd mbasic

# OR download and extract the ZIP file, then:
cd mbasic

docs.title: Step 2: Create a virtual environment
docs.text:
On Linux/Mac: 

python3 -m venv venv

On Windows: 

python -m venv venv

This creates a new directory called venv containing an isolated Python environment.

docs.title: Step 3: Activate the virtual environment
docs.text:
On Linux/Mac: 

source venv/bin/activate

On Windows (Command Prompt): 

venv\Scripts\activate.bat

On Windows (PowerShell): 

venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1

You should see (venv) appear at the beginning of your command prompt, indicating the virtual environment is active.

docs.title: Step 4: Install dependencies
docs.text:
pip install -r requirements.txt

This installs optional dependencies for specific UIs: - CLI mode: No dependencies needed (Python standard library only) - Curses mode: Requires urwid for terminal UI - Tk mode: Requires tkinter (usually pre-installed with Python) - Web mode: Requires nicegui for browser-based UI

If you only plan to use CLI mode, you can skip this step.

docs.title: Step 5: Run the interpreter
docs.text:
python3 mbasic

Or run a BASIC program:

python3 mbasic basic/bas_tests1/hello.bas

docs.title: Deactivating the virtual environment
docs.text:
When you're done, you can deactivate the virtual environment:

deactivate

docs.title: Method 2: Direct Installation (Simple)
docs.text:
If you don't want to use a virtual environment, you can run the interpreter directly:

# Navigate to the project directory
cd mbasic

# Run the interpreter (CLI mode - no dependencies required)
python3 mbasic

Note: CLI mode uses only Python's standard library and requires no external dependencies. For other UIs (Curses, Tk, Web), you'll need to install their dependencies via pip install -r requirements.txt.

docs.title: Method 3: Install as a Python Package
docs.text:
For system-wide installation:

cd mbasic
pip install -e .

After this, you can run mbasic from anywhere on your system.

docs.title: Test Interactive Mode
docs.text:
Run the interpreter without arguments:

python3 mbasic

You should see:

MBASIC 5.21 Interpreter
Ready

Ok

Try entering:

PRINT "Hello, World!"

You should see the output immediately.

docs.title: Test File Execution
docs.text:
Run one of the included test programs:

python3 mbasic basic/tests_with_results/test_operator_precedence.bas

You should see:

All 20 tests PASS

docs.title: "python3: command not found"
docs.text:
On some systems, Python 3 is available as python instead of python3:

python --version

If this shows Python 3.8 or later, you can use python instead of python3:

python mbasic

docs.title: Permission Denied on Linux/Mac
docs.text:
Make sure the script is executable:

chmod +x mbasic
./mbasic

docs.title: Virtual Environment Not Activating on Windows
docs.text:
If you get an error about execution policies in PowerShell, you may need to allow scripts:

Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser

Then try activating again.

docs.title: "Module not found" errors
docs.text: Make sure you're in the correct directory (the mbasic folder containing mbasic).

docs.title: Feature Status
docs.text: This is a comprehensive implementation of MBASIC 5.21. All core language features and statements are implemented and tested, with some hardware-specific features emulated or adapted for modern systems.

docs.title: What Works
docs.text:
• ✓ Mathematical calculations and expressions
  • ✓ String processing and manipulation
  • ✓ Arrays and data structures
  • ✓ Control flow (IF/THEN/ELSE, FOR/NEXT, WHILE/WEND, GOTO, GOSUB, ON GOTO/GOSUB)
  • ✓ Console input/output (INPUT, PRINT, PRINT USING)
  • ✓ DATA/READ/RESTORE statements
  • ✓ User-defined functions (DEF FN)
  • ✓ Interactive mode commands (RUN, LIST, SAVE, LOAD, EDIT, DELETE, RENUM, CONT)
  • ✓ Settings system (SET, SHOW SETTINGS commands with global/project configuration files)
  • ✓ Sequential file I/O (OPEN, CLOSE, PRINT#, INPUT#, LINE INPUT#, WRITE#, EOF)
  • ✓ Random file I/O (FIELD, GET, PUT, LSET, RSET, LOC, LOF)
  • ✓ Binary file I/O (MKI/MKS/MKD$, CVI/CVS/CVD)
  • ✓ Error handling (ON ERROR GOTO/GOSUB, RESUME, ERL, ERR)
  • ✓ File system operations (KILL, NAME AS, RESET)
  • ✓ Non-blocking keyboard input (INKEY$)
  • ✓ Execution tracing (TRON/TROFF)
  • ✓ SWAP statement and MID$ assignment

docs.title: What Doesn't Work
docs.text:
These are hardware-specific features that cannot work in a modern environment: - ✗ Hardware access - PEEK/POKE for hardware memory access (PEEK returns random values for compatibility) - ✗ I/O ports - INP/OUT for hardware ports - ✗ Line printer - LPRINT, LLIST (dedicated printer output)

These limitations are inherent to running vintage BASIC in a modern environment and do not affect most programs.

For complete implementation status and compatibility notes, see PROJECT_STATUS.md

  2. Make sure you're in the project directory
  3. Try running with DEBUG=1 for more detailed error messages: 
    DEBUG=1 python3 mbasic yourprogram.bas

Happy BASIC programming!

docs.title: Settings and Configuration
docs.text:
Status: The settings system is implemented and available in all UIs. Core commands (SET, SHOW SETTINGS, HELP SET) work as documented. Settings files are automatically created in ~/.mbasic/settings.json (Linux/Mac) or %APPDATA%/mbasic/settings.json (Windows). Note: Some individual settings are still planned (see status notes for each setting).

MBASIC includes a comprehensive settings system that allows you to customize its behavior. Settings can be configured globally, per-project, or per-file.

docs.title: View All Settings
docs.text: SHOW SETTINGS

docs.title: Change a Setting
docs.text:
Using SET command (in BASIC): 

SET "variables.case_conflict" "error"
SET "editor.auto_number" true

Using JSON file (in settings.json): 

{
  "variables.case_conflict": "error",
  "editor.auto_number": true
}

Note: Both methods are equivalent. SET commands affect the current session; JSON files persist across sessions.

docs.title: Get Help on a Setting
docs.text: HELP SET "variables.case_conflict"

docs.title: Settings Scope
docs.text:
Settings are applied in this order (most specific wins):

  1. File scope - Per-file settings (future feature)
  2. Project scope - .mbasic/settings.json in project directory
  3. Global scope - ~/.mbasic/settings.json in home directory
  4. Default - Built-in defaults

docs.title: Global Settings File
docs.text:
Location: - Linux/Mac: ~/.mbasic/settings.json - Windows: %APPDATA%/mbasic/settings.json (typically C:\Users\YourName\AppData\Roaming\mbasic\settings.json)

Example: 

{
  "variables.case_conflict": "first_wins",
  "editor.auto_number": true,
  "ui.theme": "dark"
}

docs.title: Project Settings File
docs.text:
Location: .mbasic/settings.json (in your project directory)

Use for project-specific preferences: 

{
  "variables.case_conflict": "error",
  "editor.auto_number_step": 5
}

docs.title: variables.case_conflict
docs.text:
Controls: How to handle variable name case variations

Type: Choice (enum)

Default: "first_wins"

Options: - "first_wins" - First usage sets the case (silent) - "error" - Flag conflicts as errors requiring user intervention - "prefer_upper" - Choose version with most uppercase letters - "prefer_lower" - Choose version with most lowercase letters - "prefer_mixed" - Prefer mixed case (camelCase/PascalCase)

Examples:

docs.title: first_wins (default)
docs.text:
10 TargetAngle = 45
20 targetangle = 90  ' Uses "TargetAngle" (first case)
30 PRINT TargetAngle  ' Displays as "TargetAngle" everywhere
Variable window shows: TargetAngle = 90

docs.title: error
docs.text:
SET "variables.case_conflict" "error"
10 TargetAngle = 45
20 targetangle = 90  ' ERROR: Variable name case conflict
Program stops with error message showing line numbers.

docs.title: prefer_upper
docs.text:
SET "variables.case_conflict" "prefer_upper"
10 TargetAngle = 45  ' 1 uppercase letter
20 targetangle = 90  ' 0 uppercase letters
30 TARGETANGLE = 100  ' 11 uppercase letters (wins)
Variable window shows: TARGETANGLE = 100

docs.title: prefer_lower
docs.text:
SET "variables.case_conflict" "prefer_lower"
10 COUNTER = 10  ' 7 uppercase letters
20 counter = 20  ' 7 lowercase letters (wins)
30 Counter = 30  ' Mixed case
Variable window shows: counter = 30

docs.title: prefer_mixed
docs.text:
SET "variables.case_conflict" "prefer_mixed"
10 myvar = 10      ' All lowercase
20 MYVAR = 20      ' All uppercase
30 MyVar = 30      ' Mixed case (wins)
Variable window shows: MyVar = 30

Use Cases: - first_wins: Default, least surprising for most users - error: Team projects requiring consistent naming - prefer_upper: Classic BASIC style (all caps) - prefer_lower: Modern Python/C style - prefer_mixed: Modern camelCase/PascalCase style

docs.title: variables.show_types_in_window
docs.text:
Controls: Show type suffixes ($, %, !, #) in variable window

Type: Boolean

Default: true

Example: 

' With show_types_in_window = true
Variable window shows: Counter%, Message$, Value!

' With show_types_in_window = false
Variable window shows: Counter, Message, Value

docs.title: editor.auto_number
docs.text:
Controls: Automatically number typed lines

Type: Boolean

Default: true

When enabled: 

' You type (without line number):
PRINT "Hello"

' MBASIC adds:
10 PRINT "Hello"

docs.title: editor.auto_number_step
docs.text:
Controls: Line number increment for auto-numbering

Type: Integer (1-1000)

Default: 10

Example: 

SET "editor.auto_number_step" 5

' Lines numbered: 5, 10, 15, 20, ...

docs.title: editor.tab_size
docs.text:
Controls: Tab width in spaces

Type: Integer (1-16)

Default: 4

docs.title: editor.show_line_numbers
docs.text:

Type: Boolean

Default: true

docs.text:

docs.text:

Type: Integer (1-3600)

Default: 30

Example:

' Program will stop after 60 seconds

Set to 0 for unlimited execution time (use with caution).

docs.title: SET Command
docs.text:
Syntax: 

SET "setting.name" value

Examples: 

SET "variables.case_conflict" "error"
SET "editor.auto_number_step" 5
SET "ui.theme" "dark"
SET "editor.show_line_numbers" true

Type Conversion: - Strings: "value" (with quotes) - Numbers: 5 (without quotes) - Booleans: true or false (lowercase, no quotes in commands; use true/false in JSON files)

docs.title: SHOW SETTINGS Command
docs.text:
Syntax: 

SHOW SETTINGS               ' Show all settings
SHOW SETTINGS "pattern"     ' Show matching settings

Examples: 

SHOW SETTINGS
' Displays all settings with current values

SHOW SETTINGS "editor"
' Shows only editor.* settings

SHOW SETTINGS "case"
' Shows settings containing "case" in name

Output Format: 

Category: Variables
  variables.case_conflict = first_wins (default)
  variables.show_types_in_window = true

Category: Editor
  editor.auto_number = true
  ...

docs.title: HELP SET Command
docs.text:
Syntax: 

HELP SET "setting.name"

Example: 

HELP SET "variables.case_conflict"

' Output:
' Setting: variables.case_conflict
' Type: enum
' Default: first_wins
' Choices: first_wins, error, prefer_upper, prefer_lower, prefer_mixed
'
' Description:
' Controls what happens when the same variable appears with different cases.
' ...

docs.title: Team Project with Consistent Naming
docs.text:
' In project .mbasic/settings.json:
{
  "variables.case_conflict": "error",
  "editor.auto_number_step": 5
}

' Now all team members must use consistent case

docs.title: Classic BASIC Style (All Caps)
docs.text:
SET "variables.case_conflict" "prefer_upper"
SET "ui.theme" "classic"

' Variables display in uppercase like vintage BASIC

docs.title: Modern Python-like Style
docs.text:
SET "variables.case_conflict" "prefer_lower"
SET "ui.theme" "dark"

' Variables display in lowercase like modern languages

docs.title: Debugging Session
docs.text:
SET "interpreter.debug_mode" true
SET "interpreter.max_execution_time" 300
RUN

' See detailed execution traces

docs.title: Scenario 1: Accidental Typos
docs.text:
Without error checking: 

' Default: first_wins
10 TotalCount = 0
20 FOR I = 1 TO 10
30   TotalCont = TotalCont + I  ' Typo! Different variable
40 NEXT I
50 PRINT TotalCount  ' Prints 0 (bug!)

With error checking: 

SET "variables.case_conflict" "error"
10 TotalCount = 0
20 FOR I = 1 TO 10
30   TotalCont = TotalCont + I
40 NEXT I

' ERROR at line 30: Variable name case conflict:
' "TotalCont" vs "TotalCount" at line 10
' Bug caught immediately!

docs.title: Scenario 2: Merging Code
docs.text:
Problem: 

' Program 1 uses:
PlayerScore = 100

' Program 2 uses:
playerscore = 200

' After MERGE:
10 PlayerScore = 100
20 playerscore = 200  ' Same variable, different case

Solution: 

SET "variables.case_conflict" "first_wins"
' Uses "PlayerScore" everywhere

' OR
SET "variables.case_conflict" "error"
' Forces you to fix the conflict

docs.title: Scenario 3: Code Style Enforcement
docs.text:
Team wants camelCase: 

SET "variables.case_conflict" "prefer_mixed"

' Team members use different cases:
10 targetangle = 45   ' All lowercase
20 TARGETANGLE = 90   ' All uppercase
30 TargetAngle = 100  ' Mixed case (camelCase)

' Variable window shows: TargetAngle
' Enforces team's camelCase style

docs.title: 1. Use error Mode for Team Projects
docs.text:
Prevents accidental case variations across team members.

' In project .mbasic/settings.json:
{
  "variables.case_conflict": "error"
}

docs.title: 2. Use first_wins for Personal Projects
docs.text: Least surprising behavior, lets you code freely.

docs.title: 3. Check Variable Window
docs.text: The Variables & Resources window ({{kbd:toggle_variables}} in TK UI) shows the canonical case being used.

docs.title: 4. Document Your Choice
docs.text:
Add a comment at the top of programs: 

10 REM Case policy: first_wins
20 REM Use consistent case for readability

docs.title: 5. Test After Changing Policies
docs.text:
SET "variables.case_conflict" "error"
RUN

' Fix any conflicts found
' Then set back to first_wins if desired

docs.title: "Case conflict error" - What to do?
docs.text:
Error message: 

Variable name case conflict: 'TargetAngle' at line 10 vs 'targetangle' at line 20

Solutions: 1. Fix the code to use consistent case 2. Change policy: SET "variables.case_conflict" "first_wins" 3. Choose a policy that picks one: "prefer_upper", "prefer_lower", etc.

docs.title: Settings not persisting?
docs.text:
Check that you're editing the right file: - Global (Linux/Mac): ~/.mbasic/settings.json - Global (Windows): %APPDATA%/mbasic/settings.json - Project: .mbasic/settings.json (create directory if needed)

Settings in files persist across sessions. Settings via SET command only affect current session.

docs.title: Which setting is being used?
docs.text:
SHOW SETTINGS "variables.case_conflict"

' Output shows:
' variables.case_conflict = error (project)
'                          ^^^^^^^ shows scope

Possible scopes: (default), (global), (project), (file)

docs.title: Create Project Settings Directory
docs.text:
mkdir -p .mbasic
cat > .mbasic/settings.json << 'EOF'
{
  "variables.case_conflict": "error",
  "editor.auto_number_step": 5,
  "ui.theme": "dark"
}
EOF

docs.title: Backup Global Settings
docs.text: cp ~/.mbasic/settings.json ~/.mbasic/settings.json.backup

docs.title: Reset to Defaults
docs.text:
Delete settings files and MBASIC will use built-in defaults: 

rm ~/.mbasic/settings.json
rm .mbasic/settings.json

docs.title: Smart Insert Workflow
docs.text: Smart Insert ({{kbd:smart_insert}}) is the fastest way to add code between existing lines. No more mental math to figure out line numbers!

docs.title: Example 1: Basic Usage
docs.text:
You have this program: 

10 PRINT "START"
20 PRINT "END"

Want to add a line between them?

  1. Click on line 10 (or position cursor anywhere on that line)
  2. Press {{kbd:smart_insert}}
  3. A blank line 15 is automatically inserted!

Result: 

10 PRINT "START"
15
20 PRINT "END"

The cursor is positioned right after the line number, ready to type.

docs.title: Example 2: No Gap - Auto Renumber
docs.text:
You have consecutive lines: 

10 PRINT "ONE"
11 PRINT "TWO"
12 PRINT "THREE"

Position cursor on line 10, press {{kbd:smart_insert}}:

A dialog appears: "No room between lines 10 and 11. Would you like to renumber the program to make room?"

Click Yes → Lines 11 onwards are renumbered to 1000, 1010, 1020... creating plenty of room!

Result: 

10 PRINT "ONE"
15
1000 PRINT "TWO"
1010 PRINT "THREE"

docs.title: Example 3: At End of Program
docs.text:
You have: 

10 PRINT "START"
20 PRINT "MIDDLE"
30 PRINT "END"

Cursor on line 30, press {{kbd:smart_insert}}:

A blank line 40 is inserted (using standard increment of 10).

Result: 

10 PRINT "START"
20 PRINT "MIDDLE"
30 PRINT "END"
40

docs.title: Smart Insert vs Manual Numbering
docs.text:
Old way (manual): 

1. Look at line 10 and line 20
2. Calculate: (10 + 20) / 2 = 15
3. Type: "15 PRINT ..."

New way (Smart Insert): 

1. Position on line 10
2. Press {{kbd:smart_insert}}
3. Start typing your code

Time saved: ~5-10 seconds per line insertion. Over a programming session, this adds up!

docs.title: 1. Write New Program
docs.text:
1. Press {{kbd:file_new}} for new program
2. Type first line: 10 PRINT "START"
3. Press Enter
4. Type next line: 20 END
5. Press {{kbd:run_program}} to run
6. Check output in lower pane
7. Press {{kbd:file_save}} to save

docs.title: 2. Expand Existing Program
docs.text:
You have a working program and need to add functionality:

1. Find the spot where new code goes
2. Press {{kbd:smart_insert}} to insert blank line
3. Type your new code
4. Press {{kbd:run_program}} to test
5. Press {{kbd:file_save}} to save

Example: 

Before:
10 INPUT "Enter number"; N
20 PRINT "You entered"; N
30 END

After (cursor on 10, {{kbd:smart_insert}} twice):
10 INPUT "Enter number"; N
15 IF N < 0 THEN PRINT "Must be positive" : GOTO 10
17 ' Validate input
20 PRINT "You entered"; N
30 END

docs.title: 3. Major Restructuring - Use Renumber
docs.text:
Your program has grown and line numbers are a mess:

1. Press {{kbd:renumber}} (Renumber dialog opens)
2. Set "Start at": 100
3. Set "Increment": 10
4. Click "Renumber"
5. All line numbers and GOTO/GOSUB references updated!

Before renumber: 

10 X=1
15 Y=2
17 GOTO 10
21 END

After renumber (start=100, increment=10): 

100 X=1
110 Y=2
120 GOTO 100
130 END

Notice: GOTO 10 automatically became GOTO 100!

docs.title: 4. Debug with Breakpoints and Variables
docs.text:
1. Click line number gutter to set breakpoint (● appears)
2. Press {{kbd:toggle_variables}} to open Variables Window
3. Press {{kbd:run_program}} to run
4. Program stops at breakpoint
5. Check variable values in Variables Window
6. Click "Step" toolbar button to step through code one statement at a time
7. Watch variables update in real-time
8. Click "Cont" toolbar button to continue running

Variables Window Features: - Click column headers to sort (Name, Value, Type) - Shows all variables and their current values - Displays variables with original case (TargetAngle, not targetangle) - Updates automatically as you step - Types displayed (integer, float, string, array) - Filter box to search for specific variables

docs.title: 5. Advanced Editing - Find and Replace
docs.text:
Large program with repeated code?

1. Press {{kbd:replace}} (Find and Replace)
2. Enter find text: "OLDVAR"
3. Enter replace text: "NEWVAR"
4. Click "Replace All"
5. All occurrences updated

docs.title: Load, Edit, Save
docs.text:
# Start with existing file
python3 mbasic --ui tk myprogram.bas

# Or load from menu
1. Press {{kbd:file_open}}
2. Browse to file
3. Click Open
4. Edit in editor
5. Press {{kbd:file_save}} to save

docs.title: Create Program Template
docs.text:
10 REM Program: [Name]
20 REM Author: [Your Name]
30 REM Date: [Date]
40 REM Purpose: [Description]
50 REM
100 ' Initialize variables
110
200 ' Main program
210
900 ' Subroutines
910
1000 END

Use {{kbd:smart_insert}} to fill in sections!

docs.title: Fix Syntax Errors
docs.text:
Red ? markers appear in line number gutter for syntax errors:

1. Look for ? in gutter
2. Read error in output pane
3. Fix the syntax
4. ? disappears automatically (100ms delay)
5. Press {{kbd:run_program}} to run

Common errors: - Missing quotes: PRINT HELLO → PRINT "HELLO" - Missing THEN: IF X=1 GOTO 100 → IF X=1 THEN GOTO 100 - Typos: PIRNT → PRINT

docs.title: Work with Arrays
docs.text:
10 DIM A(10)
20 FOR I = 1 TO 10
30   A(I) = I * 10
40 NEXT I
50 PRINT A(5)
60 END

Run with {{kbd:run_program}}, then check Variables Window ({{kbd:toggle_variables}}) to see array contents!

docs.title: Variable Case Preservation
docs.text: MBASIC now preserves the original case of your variables while maintaining case-insensitive behavior!

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
10 TargetAngle = 45
20 targetangle = 90  ' Same variable, different case
30 PRINT TargetAngle  ' Displays "TargetAngle = 90"

What you see: - Variables window shows: TargetAngle = 90 (using first case seen) - All references use the same display case - Lookups remain case-insensitive (BASIC compatibility)

docs.title: Configure Case Behavior
docs.text:
Use the settings system to control how case conflicts are handled:

' View current setting
SHOW SETTINGS "case"

' Change policy
SET "variables.case_conflict" "error"        ' Strict: flag conflicts
SET "variables.case_conflict" "first_wins"   ' Default: first case wins
SET "variables.case_conflict" "prefer_upper" ' Prefer UPPERCASE
SET "variables.case_conflict" "prefer_lower" ' Prefer lowercase
SET "variables.case_conflict" "prefer_mixed" ' Prefer CamelCase

' Get help on a setting
HELP SET "variables.case_conflict"

docs.title: Example: Catching Typos with Error Mode
docs.text:
SET "variables.case_conflict" "error"
10 TotalCount = 0
20 FOR I = 1 TO 10
30   TotalCont = TotalCont + I  ' ERROR: Typo detected!
40 NEXT I

With error mode enabled, MBASIC catches the typo at line 30 immediately!

Learn more: See docs/user/SETTINGS_AND_CONFIGURATION.md for complete settings guide.

docs.title: Improved Debugging Features
docs.text: The TK UI now provides enhanced debugging with intuitive statement highlighting.

docs.title: Next-Statement Highlighting
docs.text:
When stepping through code or hitting a breakpoint, MBASIC highlights what will execute next, not what just executed.

Example: 

10 PRINT "A"
20 PRINT "B"  ' ← Highlighted when you pause here
30 PRINT "C"

When you hit a breakpoint on line 20, you see line 20 highlighted BEFORE it executes. This lets you: - See what's about to happen - Examine variable values before the statement runs - Decide whether to step or continue

docs.title: Control Flow Visualization
docs.text:
The highlight automatically jumps to show where execution is going during GOSUB, RETURN, GOTO, NEXT, etc.

Example: 

10 PRINT "Start"
20 GOSUB 100
30 PRINT "End"   ' ← Highlights here after RETURN
40 END
100 PRINT "Sub"
110 RETURN

What you see: 1. Step at line 20 → Highlights GOSUB 100 2. Step again → Highlight jumps to line 100 (subroutine entry) 3. Step through 100, 110 4. Step at RETURN → Highlight jumps to line 30 (statement AFTER the GOSUB)

This makes control flow visible and easy to follow!

docs.title: Mid-Line Statement Stepping
docs.text:
For lines with multiple statements (colon-separated), stepping shows exactly which statement will execute:

10 PRINT "A": X=5: GOSUB 100: PRINT "B": END

Click the Stmt toolbar button (step statement) to move through each part: 1. PRINT "A" ← First 2. X=5 ← Second 3. GOSUB 100 ← Third (jumps to subroutine) 4. After RETURN: PRINT "B" ← Resumes here (not at start of line) 5. END ← Last

Click the Step toolbar button (step line) to execute the entire line at once.

docs.title: Execution Stack Window
docs.text:
Press {{kbd:toggle_stack}} to see the Execution Stack Window showing active loops and subroutine calls:

10 FOR I = 1 TO 3
20   FOR J = 1 TO 2
30     GOSUB 100
40   NEXT J
50 NEXT I
100 PRINT I; J
110 RETURN

Stack display at line 100: 

FOR I=1 TO 3 STEP 1  [I=2]
  FOR J=1 TO 2 STEP 1  [J=1]
    GOSUB from line 30

Perfect for understanding: - Nested loops - Subroutine call chains - Current loop variable values - Return addresses

docs.title: 1. Smart Insert for Rapid Development
docs.text:
Scenario: You have a skeleton program and need to flesh it out.

10 REM Initialize
100 REM Process
200 REM Output
300 END

Use Smart Insert ({{kbd:smart_insert}}) to add details under each section header without worrying about line numbers!

docs.title: 2. Renumber Before Sharing
docs.text:
Your development version might have messy line numbers: 

10 PRINT "START"
15 X=1
17 Y=2
21 GOTO 50
50 END

Before sharing, make it clean: 1. Press {{kbd:renumber}} 2. Start=10, Increment=10 3. Result: 

10 PRINT "START"
20 X=1
30 Y=2
40 GOTO 50
50 END

docs.title: 3. Use Comments Liberally
docs.text:
MBASIC supports two comment styles: 

10 REM This is a remark statement
20 ' This is also a comment (shorter!)

Add comments while developing with Smart Insert: 

10 X = 5
' {{kbd:smart_insert}} here creates line 15
15 ' Calculate result
20 Y = X * 10

docs.title: 4. Variables Window for Arrays
docs.text:
When working with arrays, keep Variables Window open:

10 DIM SCORES(5)
20 FOR I = 1 TO 5
30   INPUT "Score"; SCORES(I)
40 NEXT I

Run this with {{kbd:toggle_variables}} window open - you'll see each array element as it's filled!

docs.title: 5. Execution Stack Window for Loops
docs.text:
Press {{kbd:toggle_stack}} to see Execution Stack Window while stepping through nested loops:

10 FOR I = 1 TO 3
20   FOR J = 1 TO 2
30     PRINT I; J
40   NEXT J
50 NEXT I

The stack shows: 

FOR I=1 TO 3 STEP 1  [I=1]
  FOR J=1 TO 2 STEP 1  [J=1]

Perfect for debugging complex loop logic!

docs.title: 6. Quick Testing Cycle
docs.text:
Fastest workflow for iterative development:

Type → {{kbd:run_program}} → Check → Edit → {{kbd:run_program}} → Check → ...

No need to save between test runs! Save with {{kbd:file_save}} only when you're happy with results.

docs.title: 7. Breakpoint Shortcuts
docs.text:
Mouse: Click line number to toggle breakpoint Keyboard: Position cursor, press {{kbd:toggle_breakpoint}}

Try both and use whichever feels faster!

docs.title: Sequential File Format Compatibility
docs.text: This document covers line ending handling and CP/M file format compatibility (^Z EOF markers) for sequential file I/O. For general sequential file operations, see the OPEN, INPUT#, LINE INPUT#, and PRINT# statement documentation.

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Different operating systems use different line ending conventions:

  • CP/M, DOS, Windows: CRLF (\r\n - two characters: carriage return + line feed)
  • Unix, Linux, Mac OS X: LF (\n - single line feed character)
  • Classic Mac OS (pre-OSX): CR (\r - single carriage return character)

docs.title: Line Ending Support
docs.text:
This MBASIC implementation supports all three line ending formats for maximum cross-platform compatibility:

Line Ending Format Support Example Use CRLF ✅ Yes CP/M, DOS, Windows files LF ✅ Yes Linux, Unix, Mac OSX files CR ✅ Yes Classic Mac OS files

Important: CRLF ( ) is treated as one line ending, not two.

docs.title: Single Line Endings
docs.text:
File with different endings: 

Line1\n
Line2\r\n
Line3\r
Line4

Reads as 4 lines: 1. "Line1" (LF ending) 2. "Line2" (CRLF ending) 3. "Line3" (CR ending) 4. "Line4" (no ending, at EOF)

docs.title: Double Line Endings (Empty Lines)
docs.text:
File content: 

Line1

Line3

Reads as 3 lines: 1. "Line1" 2. "" (empty line) 3. "Line3"

Important: creates two line endings (empty line between), but is still one line ending.

docs.title: Mixed Line Endings
docs.text:
File content: 

A\r\n
B\n
C\r
D

Reads as 4 lines: "A", "B", "C", "D"

docs.title: Comparison with CP/M MBASIC 5.21
docs.text:
CP/M MBASIC 5.21 (real hardware): - Only recognizes CRLF (\r\n) as line ending - LF alone or CR alone are not recognized as line endings - Files with LF-only or CR-only endings won't read correctly

This implementation: - Recognizes all three formats (CRLF, LF, CR) - More permissive for cross-platform compatibility - Can read files created on Linux, Windows, or Mac

Why the difference?

CP/M was designed for a single platform with CRLF line endings. This implementation runs on multiple platforms (Linux, Mac, Windows) and needs to handle files from all sources.

docs.title: Testing Line Endings
docs.text:
Test program: 

10 OPEN "I", #1, "TESTFILE.TXT"
20 N = 0
30 IF EOF(1) THEN 60
40 LINE INPUT #1, A$
50 N = N + 1: PRINT N; ": ["; A$; "]"
60 IF NOT EOF(1) THEN 30
70 CLOSE #1
80 PRINT "TOTAL LINES:"; N
90 SYSTEM

The brackets [] make empty lines visible.

docs.title: CP/M File Format and ^Z (Control-Z) EOF Marker
Background
docs.text: On CP/M 1.x and 2.x systems, files were stored in 128-byte sectors. When a text file did not end exactly on a 128-byte boundary, the remaining bytes in the final sector were filled with padding. To mark the actual end of file, CP/M used a ^Z (Control-Z, ASCII 26) character as the EOF marker.

docs.title: ^Z EOF Behavior
docs.text: This MBASIC implementation correctly handles ^Z as EOF for sequential file input, matching MBASIC 5.21 behavior exactly.

docs.title: When Reading Sequential Files
docs.text:
When using INPUT # or LINE INPUT # to read from sequential files:

  1. ^Z marks end of file - Reading stops at the first ^Z character encountered
  2. Partial lines returned - If ^Z appears mid-line, the partial line up to ^Z is returned
  3. Data after ^Z ignored - Any bytes after ^Z are not read

docs.title: Example: ^Z at End of File
docs.text:
10 OPEN "I", #1, "DATA.TXT"
20 IF EOF(1) THEN 60
30 LINE INPUT #1, A$
40 PRINT A$
50 GOTO 20
60 CLOSE #1
70 PRINT "EOF reached"

If DATA.TXT contains: 

Line 1
Line 2
Line 3
^Z
Junk data
More junk

Output: 

Line 1
Line 2
Line 3
EOF reached

The "Junk data" and "More junk" lines after ^Z are not read.

docs.title: Example: ^Z Mid-Line
docs.text:
If DATA.TXT contains: 

Line 1
Line 2 has^Z more text
Line 3

Output: 

Line 1
Line 2 has
EOF reached

The text " more text" after ^Z is not read, and the partial line "Line 2 has" is returned before EOF is signaled.

docs.title: Compatibility
docs.text: This behavior matches: - ✅ MBASIC 5.21 on CP/M (tested with tnylpo emulator) - ✅ CP/M text file conventions - ✅ Most CP/M-era BASIC interpreters

docs.title: When ^Z Handling Matters
docs.text:
You need to be aware of ^Z EOF if:

  1. Reading CP/M-era files - Files created on CP/M systems may contain ^Z markers
  2. Binary data in text files - If byte value 26 (0x1A) appears in data, it will be treated as EOF
  3. Porting from CP/M - Programs written for CP/M expect this behavior

You can ignore ^Z if:

  1. Creating new files - Modern text files typically don't need ^Z markers
  2. Using random access files - ^Z is only significant for sequential (text) files
  3. Binary file I/O - Use random access mode for binary data

docs.title: Implementation Details
docs.text:
The ^Z EOF handling is implemented in _read_line_from_file() method in the interpreter:

if b == 26:  # ^Z (EOF marker in CP/M)
    file_info['eof'] = True
    if line_bytes:
        return line_bytes.decode('latin-1', errors='replace').rstrip('\r\n')
    return None

This ensures: - Byte value 26 (^Z) triggers EOF - Partial lines before ^Z are returned - EOF flag is set to prevent further reads - Behavior matches CP/M MBASIC 5.21 exactly

docs.title: Random Access Files
docs.text:
Note: ^Z is NOT significant for random access files opened with OPEN "R". Random access files:

  • Read/write fixed-length records
  • Use GET and PUT statements
  • Treat all bytes (including 26) as data
  • Do not recognize EOF markers

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Test files included in tests/ directory:

  • ctrlz.txt - Sequential file with ^Z at end
  • ctrlz2.txt - Sequential file with ^Z mid-line
  • testeof.bas - Test program for LINE INPUT
  • testeof2.bas - Test program for mid-line ^Z

Run tests: 

cd tests/
# Test with our MBASIC
python3 ../mbasic testeof.bas

# Test with real MBASIC 5.21 (requires tnylpo)
(cat testeof.bas && echo "RUN") | tnylpo ../com/mbasic.com

Both should produce identical output.
